sect1.title: Introduction

textobject.phrase: Shows &applet; applet. Contains flag and label of current keyboard layout.

sect1.para: The &applet; applet enables you to assign different layouts to your keyboard to suit different locales. The applet displays the flag and label associated with the current keyboard layout.

To add &applet; to a panel, right-click on the panel to open the panel popup menu, then choose
Add to Panel Utility &applet; .

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: To switch to a different keyboard layout, click repeatedly on the applet until the applet displays the keyboard layout that you want. If the applet does not contain the keyboard layout that you require, see for information about how to add keyboard layouts to the applet.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: To configure &applet;, right-click on the applet, then choose Preferences from the applet popup menu.

sect2.title: Keymaps
sect2.para: The Keymaps tabbed section lists the keyboard layouts that are currently configured for the applet.

sect3.title: To Modify the List of Keyboard Layouts
sect3.para: To add a keyboard layout to the Keymaps list, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Click Add in the Keymaps tabbed section. The applet displays the Select Keyboard dialog.
Click on the arrow next to the country for which you want to add a keyboard layout, then select the keyboard layout that you want to add.
Click Add to add the keyboard layout to the Keymaps list.

sect3.para: To delete a keyboard layout from the Keymaps list, select the keyboard layout, then click Delete.
To move a keyboard layout up in the Keymaps list, select the keyboard layout, then click Up. To move a keyboard layout down in the Keymaps list, select the keyboard layout, then click Down.

sect3.title: To Edit a Keyboard Layout
sect3.para: To edit a keyboard layout, select the keyboard layout, then click Edit. The Edit Keyboard dialog contains the following elements:

entry.para: The name of the keyboard layout. This name is displayed in the Keymaps tabbed section of the Preferences dialog.

A short label for the keyboard layout. For example, the label for a United States English keyboard layout is us. By default, the applet displays the flag and label of the current keyboard layout in the applet display.
The language for which the keyboard layout is adapted.
The country where the keyboard layout is used.

The flag that represents the country in which the keyboard layout is used. By default, the applet displays the flag and label of the current keyboard layout in the applet display. Click on the flag to display a flag selector dialog.
The type of keyboard for example, 101 keys, 105 keys, and so on.
The codeset that the language of the keyboard uses. For example, by default United States English uses the Western European ISO-8859-1 codeset.
The command that the applet uses to change to the keyboard layout. You can use any of the following commands to change the keyboard layout:
gkb_xmmap us where us is the file extension of the xmodmap file for the keyboard layout.
xmodmap /path/xmodmap.us where /path/xmodmap.us is the xmodmap file for the keyboard layout.
setxkbmap us where us is the file extension of the xmodmap file for the keyboard layout.

listitem.para: Select one of the following options from the drop-down list box to specify what the applet displays in the panel:
Flag and Label: display a flag and label.
You must reboot your machine to effect a change to this setting.
Select one of the following options from the drop-down list box to specify the size of the applet in the panel:
You must reboot your machine to effect a change to this setting.

You can use a shortcut key to switch between keyboard layouts. To customize the shortcut key, click Grab hotkey, then press the keys that you want to use. The applet displays the shortcut key in the text box. The default shortcut key is AltShift which the applet displays in the text box as Mod1-Shift_L.
